Hi David,

I've recently noticed with NUnit (which does allow mixed numeric comparisons
to succeed) that the problem arises more often with the Assert.That syntax.
Something to watch for...

Charlie

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On 
> Behalf Of David Saff
> Sent: Thursday, June 28, 2007 1:58 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] should new Integer(1) equal new Long(1)
> 
> All,
> 
> Kent and I continue to try to fine-tune equality to produce 
> the least surprise, and continue to wonder if well enough 
> should have been left alone.  In 4.3, we introduced some 
> run-time math magic to make up for the lack of type-expansion 
> once we had removed most of the primitive type assertEquals 
> methods.  Thus, it became the case, somewhat accidentally, 
> that this would pass:
> 
> assertEquals(new Integer(1), new Long(1));  // A
> 
> However, it simultaneously became the case that this would also pass:
> 
> assertEquals(new BigDecimal("1.0"), new BigDecimal("1.1"));  // B
> 
> Line B should certainly fail.  The simplest thing to do is to 
> remove our math magic, introduce assertEquals(long, long), 
> etc, and let numerical classes define their own equality.  
> This means that line A will now fail, since that's how 
> Integer.equals() is defined.  This is a small behavior 
> change, but a "regression" of sorts.
> 
> If anyone believes this is a damaging decision, please let me know.
> 
>    David Saff
> 
>
